classes.docstring: """The test client has been asked to follow a redirect loop."""
classes.name: RedirectCycleError

classes.docstring:
"""
    A wrapper around BytesIO that restricts what can be read since data from
    the network can't be sought and cannot be read outside of its content
    length. This makes sure that views can't do anything under the test client
    that wouldn't work in real life.
    """
classes.name: FakePayload

classes.docstring:
"""
    An HTTP Handler that can be used for testing purposes. Use the WSGI
    interface to compose requests, but return the raw HttpResponse object with
    the originating WSGIRequest attached to its ``wsgi_request`` attribute.
    """
classes.name: ClientHandler

classes.docstring:
"""
    Class that lets you create mock Request objects for use in testing.

    Usage:

    rf = RequestFactory()
    get_request = rf.get('/hello/')
    post_request = rf.post('/submit/', {'foo': 'bar'})

    Once you have a request object you can pass it to any view function,
    just as if that view had been hooked up using a URLconf.
    """
classes.name: RequestFactory

classes.docstring:
"""
    Class that lets you create mock ASGI-like Request objects for use in
    testing. Usage:

    rf = AsyncRequestFactory()
    get_request = await rf.get('/hello/')
    post_request = await rf.post('/submit/', {'foo': 'bar'})

    Once you have a request object you can pass it to any view function,
    including synchronous ones. The reason we have a separate class here is:
    a) this makes ASGIRequest subclasses, and
    b) AsyncTestClient can subclass it.
    """
classes.name: AsyncRequestFactory

classes.docstring:
"""
    Mixin with common methods between Client and AsyncClient.
    """
classes.name: ClientMixin

classes.docstring:
"""
    A class that can act as a client for testing purposes.

    It allows the user to compose GET and POST requests, and
    obtain the response that the server gave to those requests.
    The server Response objects are annotated with the details
    of the contexts and templates that were rendered during the
    process of serving the request.

    Client objects are stateful - they will retain cookie (and
    thus session) details for the lifetime of the Client instance.

    This is not intended as a replacement for Twill/Selenium or
    the like - it is here to allow testing against the
    contexts and templates produced by a view, rather than the
    HTML rendered to the end-user.
    """
classes.name: Client

classes.docstring:
"""
    An async version of Client that creates ASGIRequests and calls through an
    async request path.

    Does not currently support "follow" on its methods.
    """
classes.name: AsyncClient
